quiz.quizTitle: GCSE Biology: Blood and Organ Donation
quiz.summary: This quiz covers key aspects of blood, organ, and stem cell donation, including reasons for donation, the donation process, legal considerations, and reasons for choosing not to donate. It features a mix of multiple-choice, short-answer, and true/false questions, ensuring comprehensive coverage of the provided study material.
quiz.subject: biology
quiz.syllabusAlignment: GCSE Triple Science Biology topics related to human health and medical procedures, specifically donation.

questions.prompt: According to the provided material, approximately how many new blood donors are needed every day in England to meet demand?
questions.explanation: Page 6 states, "Nearly 400 new blood donors are needed every day in England to meet demand."

questions.prompt: Identify two types of patients who might require a stem cell donation.
questions.answer: Patients with blood cancer or a blood disorder.
questions.explanation: Page 5 indicates that "Someone with blood cancer or a blood disorder" might need a stem cell donation.

questions.prompt: True or False: Since 2020, in England, individuals under 18 are automatically considered organ donors unless they have registered a decision not to donate.
questions.explanation: Page 13 states, "From 2020, anyone over 18 in England will be considered an organ donor when they die unless they have registered a decision not to donate or are in an excluded group." This explicitly refers to those "over 18", not under.

questions.prompt: What is the minimum age required to register online to become a blood donor in England, according to the provided information?
questions.explanation: Page 8, step 1, states: "Register online from 16+ at blood.co.uk."

questions.prompt: Describe the two methods by which stem cells can be donated, and state which method accounts for the majority of donations.
questions.answer: Stem cells can be donated through the bloodstream (90% of donors) or via a bone marrow donation procedure (10% of donors). The bloodstream method accounts for the majority of donations.
questions.explanation: Page 10, step 4 under 'Donate', outlines that stem cells can be donated "through the bloodstream (90% of donors)" or through a "bone marrow donation procedure (10% of donors)".

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a reason explicitly mentioned in the material for why an individual might choose not to donate blood?
questions.explanation: Page 16 includes a speech bubble stating, "I'm really scared of needles, so giving blood isn't something I feel I'm able to do."
